    <item>
      <title>Malcolm Turnbull consulted his wife, Lucy, over minister-staff sex ban</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/18/malcolm-turnbull-consulted-his-wife-lucy-over-minister-staff-sex-ban</link>
      <description><p>PM says his criticism of Barnaby Joyce ‘would have overwhelming endorsement of Australians’</p><p>The ministerial sex ban <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/malcolm-turnbull">Malcolm Turnbull </a>imposed on his government was “one of those classic issues” where he sought the counsel of his wife, Lucy, the prime minister has revealed.</p><p>In an interview for 60 minutes, Turnbull maintained he <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/18/turnbull-says-he-has-nothing-to-apologise-for-over-barnaby-joyce-row">had no regrets</a> about the public flaying he gave his deputy, Barnaby Joyce, over his affair with a former staffer. Turnbull said he spoke for the nation despite his now-infamous comments that threatened to tear the Coalition apart.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/18/malcolm-turnbull-consulted-his-wife-lucy-over-minister-staff-sex-ban">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>George Christensen reported to police over gun photo aimed at 'greenie' rivals</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/18/george-christensen-reported-to-police-over-gun-photo-aimed-at-greenie-rivals</link>
      <description><p>Screenshot from Queensland LNP politician’s Facebook page is sent to police by Greens candidate Ben Pennings who said he received death threats</p><p>The Queensland LNP politician George Christensen has been referred to police over a Facebook post showing the MP holding a handgun and the comment “Do you feel lucky, greenie punks?”<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/15/florida-shooting-suspect-charged-questions-nikolas-cruz"> </a></p><p>Ben Pennings, who is running for the lead <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/jan/05/larissa-waters-faces-tough-internal-challenge-for-greens-spot-in-senate">position on the Queensland Greens Senate ticket</a>, said he sent police the screenshot of Christensen’s post after receiving “numerous” death threats from central and north Queensland.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/18/george-christensen-reported-to-police-over-gun-photo-aimed-at-greenie-rivals">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Trump: FBI 'spending too much time' on Russia inquiry and missed Florida shooter signs</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/donald-trump-fbi-russia-inquiry-florida-shooting</link>
      <description><p>The president’s attempt to use the shooting to make a political point about the Russia inquiries drew swift criticism</p><p>Donald Trump has criticized the FBI for missing the “many signals” about the Florida school shooter, saying the agency was spending “too much time” trying to prove Russian collusion with the Trump campaign. <br></p><p>The US president’s attempt to use the shooting to make a political point about the FBI’s Russia inquiries into the Trump campaign drew swift criticism, including from John Kasich, the Republican governor of Ohio, who told CNN it was an “absurd statement”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/18/donald-trump-fbi-russia-inquiry-florida-shooting">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>More Nauru refugees depart for US as attack on Manus provokes panic</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/more-nauru-refugees-depart-for-us-as-attack-on-manus-provokes-panic</link>
      <description><ul><li>Iranians excluded from group of 35 refugees </li><li>Men on Manus Island allege PNG soldiers attacked them<br></li></ul><p>Another 35 refugees are leaving Nauru for the United States on Sunday, the third group to depart Australia’s offshore immigration centres this week.<br><br>Almost all are single Afghan, Pakistani or Rohingya men, along with one Sri Lankan family and one Bangladeshi refugee, said Ian Rintoul of the the Refugee Action Coalition.</p><p>The makeup further confirms fears that Iranians, who make up the largest national group on Nauru, have so far been excluded from the US intake. Iran was proscribed by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/trumps-travel-ban">Donald Trump’s “travel ban”</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/more-nauru-refugees-depart-for-us-as-attack-on-manus-provokes-panic">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Israel ready to act against 'dangerous' Iran, Netanyahu warns</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/netanyahu-israel-ready-act-against-dangerous-iran-munich-speech</link>
      <description><p>Tehran will not be allowed to put ‘noose of terror around our neck’, PM says in Munich speech</p><p>Benjamin Netanyahu has said that Israel will act directly against Iran if necessary, not just its allies in the Middle East, reiterating his country’s position that Tehran was the world’s greatest threat.</p><p> As tensions increase in the Middle East over Iran’s role in Syria and Yemen and as Donald Trump presses for a tougher approach on Tehran, Israel is seeking wider support for efforts to contain its regional nemesis.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/netanyahu-israel-ready-act-against-dangerous-iran-munich-speech">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Nigeria releases 475 Boko Haram suspects for rehabilitation</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/nigeria-releases-475-boko-haram-suspects-for-rehabilitation</link>
      <description><p>Authorities said some suspected of links with militants had been held without trial since 2010<br></p><p>A Nigerian court has released 475 people allegedly affiliated with Boko Haram for rehabilitation, the justice ministry said, as the country’s biggest legal investigation of the militant Islamist insurgency continued.</p><p> The first person convicted for the kidnapping in 2014 of Chibok schoolgirls, sentenced to 15 years’ imprisonment last week, was also handed an additional 15-year sentence, to run back-to-back, the ministry said in a statement.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/nigeria-releases-475-boko-haram-suspects-for-rehabilitation">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Iran plane crash in south of country 'kills all 65 onboard'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/iran-plane-crashes-aseman-airlines-yasuj</link>
      <description><p>Aseman Airlines plane crashed en route from Tehran to Yasuj in severe weather conditions, according to state media reports</p><p>All passengers and crew onboard an Iranian commercial flight died after the plane crashed amid severe weather conditions in a mountainous region in the south of the country, state television reported on Sunday. </p><p>Aseman Airlines flight 3705, en route from Tehran to the southern city of Yasuj, the capital of the impoverished province of Kohgiluyeh and Boyer-Ahmad, went off radar 50 minutes into its journey, not far from its destination.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/iran-plane-crashes-aseman-airlines-yasuj">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jokhang temple: fire engulfs ancient 'heart' of Tibetan Buddhism</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/jokhang-temple-fire-engulfs-ancient-heart-of-tibetan-buddhism</link>
      <description><p>Concern over extent of damage to politically sensitive site as Chinese authorities play down blaze</p><p>A large fire has damaged one of the holiest and most politically sensitive sites in Tibet, the Jokhang temple, stirring an outpouring of grief and concern among Tibetans.<br></p><p><a href="https://twitter.com/RobbieBarnett/status/964851351154036737">Dramatic video footage</a> posted on social media showed flames devouring part of the seventh-century <a href="http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/707">Unesco world heritage site</a> in Tibet’s spectacular high-altitude capital, Lhasa, on Saturday.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/jokhang-temple-fire-engulfs-ancient-heart-of-tibetan-buddhism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Free stronger flu vaccine for older Australians after 2017's deadly outbreak</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/free-stronger-flu-vaccine-for-older-australians-after-2017s-deadly-outbreak</link>
      <description><p>Government announces $31m program after mutation in virus contributed to more than 1,100 deaths last year</p><p>Older Australians will be given free, stronger flu vaccinations by the federal government in an effort to prevent another deadly outbreak.</p><p>More than 1,100 people across Australia died from the flu last year, with most of them over the age of 65.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/18/free-stronger-flu-vaccine-for-older-australians-after-2017s-deadly-outbreak">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/society/flu">Flu</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/health">Health</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australia-news">Australia news</category>

      <title>'Plagiarism': Spain's manchego makers in Mexican standoff over famed cheese</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/plagiarism-spains-manchego-makers-in-mexican-standoff-over-famed-cheese</link>
      <description><p>Calls for Mexico’s cheesemakers to stop using the name are threatening a new trade deal between Latin American country and the EU</p><p>The producers of Spain’s renowned manchego cheese have accused their Mexican counterparts of “crude plagiarism” in a row that is holding back a new trade deal between the EU and Mexico.</p><p>“We have to defend our manchego tooth and nail,” says Francisco Tejado, walking through the factory of Spain’s biggest cheese producer, Garcia Baquero, located in the arid plains of La Mancha, the region famed for the cheese.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/plagiarism-spains-manchego-makers-in-mexican-standoff-over-famed-cheese">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/boy-with-epilepsy-denied-cannabis-oil-treatment-reduce-seizures-government-refuses-licence</link>
      <description><p>Government refuses to issue licence for medication that reduces six-year-old’s seizures</p><p>The government has refused to issue a licence for a six-year-old boy with a rare form of epilepsy to be treated with cannabis oil, despite evidence that it has eased his symptoms and support from MPs.</p><p>Alfie Dingley, from Kenilworth, Warwickshire, can suffer up to 30 seizures a day. His mother said they had decreased dramatically in number and severity while he was in the Netherlands being treated with a prescribed, cannabis-based medication.<br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/boy-with-epilepsy-denied-cannabis-oil-treatment-reduce-seizures-government-refuses-licence">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Selma Blair: 'I'll lose everything, I'll go to court'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/global/2018/feb/18/selma-blair-ill-lose-everything-ill-go-to-court-i-will-be-on-the-right-side-of-history-</link>
      <description><p>Selma Blair kept asking herself why she didn’t just hit James Toback and run out of the room. A leading voice in exposing Hollywood talks single parenthood, stray dogs and how speaking out helped her</p><p>Halfway through our interview, Selma Blair’s one-eyed dog Buster climbs on to the restaurant table at the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/travel/2011/sep/28/rock-n-roll-hotels-chateau-marmont">Chateau Marmont</a> in LA and happily devours an entire plate of leafy greens. Strangers are staring. I’m staring. “Are you disgusted that I’m letting my dog do this?” Selma asks, her face serious, her tone as drily hilarious as it has been for the past hour, even when discussing the state of Hollywood for women and her fears that she’ll never work again. In fact, I’m just amazed that, here in Hollywood, even rescue mutts with part of their face missing seem to enjoy rocket salad with a blue cheese dressing. “I wonder if it’s possible to overdose on arugula?” she thinks aloud. “We’ll see when the dog dies tonight.”</p><p>Blair made her name with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2017/dec/18/cruel-intentions-the-musical-le-poisson-rouge-off-broadway"><em>Cruel Intentions</em></a>, a 1999 mean-teen remake of <em>Dangerous Liaisons</em>, and has since acted in <em>Legally Blonde</em>, the <em>Hellboy</em> films directed by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/05/guillermo-del-toro-oscar-frontrunner-dga-award-the-shape-of-water">Guillermo del Toro</a> and in the US remake of <em>Kath &amp; Kim</em>, where she played the hysterically funny and spoiled daughter. More recently she played Kris Jenner in an episode of <em>American Crime Story. </em>Now she’s in a comedy-ish horror film called <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/sep/10/mom-and-dad-review-nicolas-cage-toronto-film-festival-tiff"><em>Mom and Dad</em></a>, which isn’t going down too well in America, what with its theme of parents overtaken by the urge to murder their own children, though Blair’s performance has been praised by the <em>Hollywood Reporter</em>, which describes her as a “<a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/mom-dad-review-1037605">chronically underused talent</a>”. Nicolas Cage plays her husband, and they spend half the movie trying to end their two kids with an assortment of homemade weaponry.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global/2018/feb/18/selma-blair-ill-lose-everything-ill-go-to-court-i-will-be-on-the-right-side-of-history-">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Maude Julien: 'How I escaped from my father's cult'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/maude-julien-how-i-escaped-from-my-fathers-cult</link>
      <description><p>Maude Julien’s father tried to turn her into a ‘superhuman’ through a series of cruel experiments. Now aged 60, she recalls how she survived her her horrifying upbringing and began to lead a happy and well-balanced life</p><p>In 1936, a 34-year-old French businessman called Louis Didier struck a bargain with a poor mining couple in Lille: he persuaded them to give him their six-year-old daughter, Jeannine. Didier would provide the girl with material security and a university-level education and in return, her parents would never see her again. For Didier the handover was a day of grave significance, the first big step towards realising his life’s ambition.</p><p>His plan was to use Jeannine to give him a child that he would then sculpt into what he envisaged would be a superhuman. The child would be raised to be able to survive concentration camps and withstand torture under interrogation. Didier’s confused and hostile worldview took shape during the years between the First and Second World Wars and he was convinced that, if properly physically, mentally and emotionally trained from birth, it would be possible for a person to transcend normal human reality. He embarked on his project.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/maude-julien-how-i-escaped-from-my-fathers-cult">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Please park the tired ‘unlucky-in-love’ Jennifer Aniston storyline | Barbara Ellen</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/please-park-unlucky-in-love-jennifer-aniston-storyline</link>
      <description><p>The film star has announced her separation from Justin Theroux. The response to her perfectly normal relationship trajectory is entirely predictable</p><p>The marriage of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/jennifer-aniston" title="">Jennifer Aniston</a> and Justin Theroux has ended “lovingly”. How does that even work? “Get out of my life! (I love you).” “I never want to see your miserable face again (You lit up my world).” “Don’t pack my coffee maker – you thief! (We will always have Paris).” However, Aniston and Theroux are managing it and good luck to them. I wish them well in what may be their last shared quest not to end up becoming as annoying and smug as Gwyneth Paltrow and Chris&nbsp;Martin, the celebrity couple who inadvertently proved that there <em>can</em> be such a thing as an over-civilised divorce.</p><p>In particular, good luck to Aniston, who, though she’s done a bit of acting, must now return to her proper day job of being described as “unlucky in love” in eight out of 10 articles written about her, the ninth usually written about her <a href="http://www.cosmopolitan.com/entertainment/celebs/a18208903/jennifer-aniston-brad-pitt-tweets/" title="">getting back with Brad Pitt</a> (after approximately 13 years apart) and the tenth rudely insinuating that she is too old for bikinis.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/please-park-unlucky-in-love-jennifer-aniston-storyline">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Peter Bradshaw's predictions for the 2018 film Baftas</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2018/feb/18/film-baftas-peter-bradshaw-predictions-2018-death-stalin-lady-macbeth</link>
      <description><p>Will Brit hopefuls Lady Macbeth and The Death of Stalin triumph? And will Daniel Day-Lewis get a final gong before retiring? Our chief critic places his bets</p><p>The Baftas are almost here, exciting news for the truly excellent British films which could well be rewarded: Lady Macbeth, The Death of Stalin, God’s Own Country. There could well be a final Bafta for one of Britain’s great screen actors, Daniel Day-Lewis (although he has dual citizenship with the Republic of Ireland) who is bowing out with a sensational performance, in fact one of his very best, as the enigmatic 1950s fashion designer Reynolds Woodcock in Paul Thomas Anderson’s Phantom Thread. My guess is that Guillermo Del Toro’s swooning romance The Shape of Water will be the big winner, but that Greta Gerwig’s tremendous autobiographical coming-of-age comedy Lady Bird will have a real showing, largely because of a possible win for Saoirse Ronan in the lead. It is a real disappointment that Bafta voters could not find it in their collective hearts to include a female director on the nomination list. This could have gone, in my view to Gerwig, or to Dee Rees for Mudbound, or even to the brilliantly talented Anna Biller for her The Love Witch. Anyway, here are my predictions:</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2018/feb/18/film-baftas-peter-bradshaw-predictions-2018-death-stalin-lady-macbeth">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>My husband died and my son is angry I’m in a new relationship | Dear Mariella</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/my-husband-died-and-my-son-is-angry-i-am-in-a-new-relationship-mariella-frostrup</link>
      <description><p>Mothers and sons is the greatest love story never told, says Mariella Frostrup. Stay patient but don’t stop seeing your new lover</p><p><strong><em>The dilemma</em></strong><em> My husband died suddenly early last year. It has been tough for me and for my teen/20s children. We’ve worked hard to support our grief and have been close. They have lovely friends and special loves who have been wonderful and supportive – and they are OK, me too.</em></p><p><em>I have become close to someone I have known vaguely for 10 years. He is lovely and we seem to have embarked on something special. In our 50s neither of us want to fanny about and he seems willing to accept the baggage I carry (and he has some, too).&nbsp;I feel the same. </em></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/my-husband-died-and-my-son-is-angry-i-am-in-a-new-relationship-mariella-frostrup">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/relationships">Relationships</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/family">Family</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <pubDate>Sun, 18 Feb 2018 06:00:36 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/18/my-husband-died-and-my-son-is-angry-i-am-in-a-new-relationship-mariella-frostrup</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/4da48a491f82d210e0476d228651ac1a361879af/0_0_4734_2840/master/4734.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=75f84302c6e30c3091f4d367be32cc96">

    <item>
      <title>Is your partner micro-cheating? Let’s face it, whose isn’t…</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/16/is-your-partner-micro-cheating-whose-isnt</link>
      <description><p>So your partner shows a fleeting interest in other men or women? Congratulations… you’ve probably picked well</p><p>Are you guilty of <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-5257227/Psychologist-explains-micro-cheating-rise.html">“micro-cheating”</a>? I’d forgive you for having no clue, because I’ve now read about two dozen articles on this latest pop-psychology buzzphrase, which <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/2017/08/15/micro-cheating-what-is-it-and-does-it-count_a_23077600/">went viral</a> last month, and I’m more confused than when I started. It refers, as far as I can tell, to seemingly innocuous behaviours that actually count as infidelity. But the examples given by dating experts range from wishing someone happy birthday on Facebook, which plainly isn’t a problem, to taking off your wedding ring before chatting someone up in a bar, which plainly is. (Does your partner <a href="https://www.bustle.com/p/7-signs-someone-is-micro-cheating-on-you-according-to-experts-7932780">talk about their ex</a> too much? That’s micro-cheating. But what’s “too much”? No one will say.) Confusing matters further, micro-cheating apparently also includes things that are obviously signs that your partner is having an affair of the conventional variety. If he spends ages staring goggle-eyed at pictures of another woman on his phone, while you look grumpy on the other side of the bed, there are only two possibilities: either you’re posing for <a href="https://www.gettyimages.com/photos/infidelity">stock photos</a> for magazine articles on relationship problems, or you’ve got a relationship problem.</p><p>Micro-cheating is an unhelpful idea, as the psychologist <a href="https://www.thecut.com/2018/01/micro-cheating-what-it-is-and-why-its-an-unhelpful-concept.html">Justin Lehmiller noted on The Cut website</a>, because it implies that feeling the tiniest attraction to anyone else is a red flag – a notion so at odds with normal human functioning that it sets a standard no relationship could ever meet. Beyond that, like the idea of the “emotional affair” before it, it seems destined to worry or reassure precisely the wrong people. If you’re needy and insecure, you’ll suspect your partner is micro-cheating when they aren’t – possibly even driving them away, creating the very breach you feared. Conversely, if you’re trying to avoid confronting the truth that your relationship is in trouble, you’ll take false comfort if your partner’s actions happen not to tick any boxes on the micro-cheating list.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/16/is-your-partner-micro-cheating-whose-isnt">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Turnbull’s attack on Emma Alberici’s tax-cut analysis doesn’t add up | Greg Jericho</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2018/feb/18/turnbulls-attack-on-emma-albericis-tax-cut-analysis-doesnt-add-up</link>
      <description><p>There’s a bit of smoke and mirrors involved when companies say tax concessions are needed to increase wages</p><p>The battle over company tax cuts is hotting up and the response by the government and the business sector to analysis by ABC’s Emma Alberici – on the impact of such tax cuts and <a href="http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-02-14/why-many-big-companies-dont-pay-corporate-tax/9443840">evidence</a> that one in five of the largest corporations in Australia paid no tax over the past three years – shows how worried they are that they are losing the fight. </p><p>On the same day Alberici’s article was published, <a href="https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Hansard/Hansard_Display?bid=chamber/hansardr/39bf6e71-561a-493e-a0e3-ad1c932ff1f4/&amp;sid=0085">the prime minister referred to it during question time</a> as “one of the most confused and poorly researched articles I’ve seen on this topic on the ABC’s website”. Meanwhile, the Qantas chief executive, Alan Joyce, argued <a href="https://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/aviation/qantas-rubbishes-nonsense-notion-it-shouldnt-push-tax-cuts/news-story/48de642a3bd2e498372f3fa3bd0ea53c">in the Australian</a> that there were good reasons why the airline hadn’t paid tax in the past and that whether it did or not was irrelevant when it came to the issue of arguing for a lower tax rate. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/grogonomics/2018/feb/18/turnbulls-attack-on-emma-albericis-tax-cut-analysis-doesnt-add-up">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/pope-francis-attitude-abuse-scandal-catholic-church-critics</link>
      <description>He entered office on a wave of energy but, as discontent grows over his attitude to abuse scandals, Francis faces opposition on all sides<p>Chatham House is one of the most important foreign affairs thinktanks in the UK. But on Wednesday its focus will not be a president, or an organisation like the World Bank, or the future of the EU after Brexit, but a religious leader: Pope Francis. And it will be the third time in recent weeks that Britain has turned its attention to the pope.</p><p>Two weeks ago, the Foreign Office-sponsored thinktank Wilton Park took delegates to the Vatican to meet the pope and discuss violent religious extremism, while last week the Metropolitan police commissioner, Cressida Dick, was in Rome to talk with Francis about modern slavery.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/pope-francis-attitude-abuse-scandal-catholic-church-critics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Gus Kenworthy's kiss with boyfriend on NBC greeted with acclaim</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics</link>
      <description><p>The British-born American freestyle skier failed to add to his silver from Sochi, but a historic kiss with his boyfriend on primetime network TV may have made an even bigger impact back home</p><p>When the American freestyle skier Gus Kenworthy shared a kiss with boyfriend Matthew Wilkas at the bottom of the hill before Sunday morning’s ski slopestyle qualifying, neither was immediately aware the moment was captured by NBC’s cameras.</p><p>But the significance of an openly gay male athlete kissing another man on primetime network television during one of the world’s biggest collective experiences was not lost on the Saturday night audience back home in the United States where it quickly went viral and was feted by LGBT activists as a marker of progress amid the <a href="https://www.outsports.com/2018/2/9/16997928/nbc-winter-olympics-lgbt-opening-ceremony">broadcaster’s much-criticized handling</a> of gay athletes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/18/gus-kenworthy-kiss-boyfriend-olympics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><ul><li>Sydney FC 0-2 Melbourne City at Allianz Stadium</li><li>Wales international scores one and has a hand in another</li></ul><p>Three years, three titles.       <title>George Groves beats Chris Eubank Jr on points despite shoulder injury drama</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/george-groves-chris-eubank-jr-fight-report</link>
      <description><p>• Groves sees out last round with one arm immobilised<br>• Londoner into World Boxing Super Series final after brutal fight</p><p>George Groves finished a wild night in Manchester with his left arm hanging redundantly by his side, his WBA super-middleweight title intact, a cheque for £1.6m safely lodged and the prospect of more to come in the final of the World Boxing Super Series in London on 2 June.</p><p>Chris Eubank Jr, cruelly, went home to Brighton with nothing but a significant blood deficit from gaping cuts across his features and the acknowledgment of a capacity crowd whose jeers turned to cheers after his full-throttle effort to blow the Londoner out of the ring over 12 rounds. It was little comfort, although they might do it all again once this tournament is over. Groves now awaits the winner of next weekend’s semi-final in Nuremberg between the unbeaten Liverpudlian Callum Smith and Jürgen Brähmer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2018/feb/17/george-groves-chris-eubank-jr-fight-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><ul><li>CEO says AFLW has ‘no budget’ for lighting<br></li><li>Fremantle, GWS, Brisbane and Adelaide winners in round three</li></ul><p>AFLW CEO Nicole Livingstone has said the AFLW has no budget for lighting “for the rest of the season”, as Brisbane Lions coach Craig Starcevich slammed the quality of lighting at Princes Park, suggesting it could be a safety hazard for players.</p><p>The Lions returned to the winners’ circle on Saturday night after their impressive 22-point win over Carlton 6.4 (40) to 2.6 (18).     <item>
      <title>Is there any hope for truth? I went to a conference to find out | Rhik Samadder</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/is-there-any-hope-for-truth-i-went-to-a-conference-to-find-out</link>
      <description><p>From bot factories weaponising misinformation to Twitter trolls polluting online debate, we are all living in a fake news world – unless, it turns out, you are a teen</p><p>Have we destroyed truth? How can we live in a fake news world? When will The Experts Strike Back? To find out, I blagged my way into an academic event, looking for answers. <a href="https://www.knowledgequarter.london/kq-conference-2018/future-of-knowledge-2018/">The Future of Knowledge</a> was hosted by Knowledge Quarter, an assembly of organisations in the King’s Cross area that includes Soas, the British Library, the British Museum and the Institute of Physics – a bit like <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2011/sep/22/your-next-box-set-avengers">The Avengers</a>.</p><p>On one of the panels was historian and film-maker <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/david-olusoga">David Olusoga</a>, the smartest, most miserable man I have ever heard speak. “The historian Oswald Spengler said that optimism is cowardice,” he began. He went on to draw parallels between now and the 1920s, both being characterised by a flight from reason and the rise of propaganda. Our age is different, he said, because it is worse. He is right. Social media – anonymous, empowering and narcissistic – has polluted our debates. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/apr/02/putin-kremlin-inside-russian-troll-house">Bot factories in Russia have weaponised misinformation</a>, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/03/donald-trump-boasts-nuclear-button-bigger-kim-jong-un">Trump edges us closer to nuclear extinction with a tweet</a>, yet after a hard weekend hitting the Häagen-Dazs I can’t post a picture of my nipples on Instagram? I have lost track of what I was saying. That is another thing: <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/05/crimes-of-attention-stalkers-killers-jihadists-longing">we all have shorter attention spans</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/is-there-any-hope-for-truth-i-went-to-a-conference-to-find-out">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Lena Dunham’s hysterectomy choice is hers alone – whatever some people may think | Barbara Ellen</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/lena-dunham-choice-her-own-whatever-some-women-may-think</link>
      <description>The Girls creator deserves compassion, not condemnation, for her decision to have a hysterectomy<p>Only the hardest of hearts would not feel sympathy for <em>Girls</em> creator, Lena Dunham, right now. She’s <a href="https://www.vogue.com/article/lena-dunham-hysterectomy-vogue-march-2018-issue" title="">written – extremely eloquently – in <em>Vogue</em></a> about how, after many years suffering from crippling endometriosis, she elected to have a hysterectomy.</p><p>My first reaction was shock – Dunham is a young woman: did she really have to do something so final? (She writes in the article about her sadness about not being able to carry a child.) In other coverage, experts (and the not-so-expert) expressed consternation – it wasn’t even certain that the hysterectomy would eliminate all the problems. (Put very simplistically, endometriosis occurs outside the uterus and Dunham is keeping her ovaries.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/lena-dunham-choice-her-own-whatever-some-women-may-think">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>After Florida, I see the NRA as nothing less than a terrorist organization</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/the-week-in-patriarchy-florida-school-shooting-nra</link>
      <description><p>What else would you call a group that ensures I need to have a conversation with my daughter about how to survive a school shooting? </p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/info/2017/jan/19/this-week-in-the-patriarchy-jessica-valenti-email">Get this newsletter via email – sign up</a><br></li></ul><p>I try so hard not to let tragedies like the one that happened <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/florida-school-shooting">at a Florida high school this week</a> feel like just another shooting. This happens so often, it’s easy to fall into frozen despair. If child after child is killed, and still our politicians do nothing – how can we expect anything to change?</p><p>The truth is that we have to stop voting for Republicans; we have to stop voting for people who take money from the NRA. At this point, I consider them nothing less than a terrorist organization – what else would you call a group that ensures I have to have a conversation with my seven-year-old about playing dead should she be unable to run away from a shooter. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/the-week-in-patriarchy-florida-school-shooting-nra">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>I was a pawn in one of the great comedy crimes | Stewart Lee</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/i-was-a-pawn-in-one-of-the-great-comedy-crimes-david-chappelle</link>
      <description><p>David Chappelle claimed he was late onstage because my act had overrun, but perhaps he was constructing an elaborate alibi…</p><p>The weekend before last, my curator friend worried there had been a burglary at his Bloomsbury Museum of Comedy, but nothing was taken. Perhaps some obsessed comedy fan had wanted to caress the stuffed bear from <em>Steptoe and Son</em> with Matthew Corbett’s Sooty puppet while dressed in Freddie Starr’s yellow teddy boy jacket?</p><p>Aware of the impossibility of working out new stuff in front of similarly obsessed fans, especially in the digital surveillance era, the American comedian David Chappelle <a href="https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/how-dave-chappelle-is-creating-844886" title="">seals his audience’s phones in locked bags</a>. I confiscate any I see from the stage and stick them into my anus. But if there were ever more than one a night it would be a squeeze, even for someone with my medical&nbsp;history.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/i-was-a-pawn-in-one-of-the-great-comedy-crimes-david-chappelle">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>If the abused can’t speak, we need other routes to their pain | Andy Connolly</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/if-abused-cant-speak-we-need-other-routes-to-their-pain-barry-bennell</link>
      <description>It took decades before any of Barry Bennell’s abuse victims came forward – we need to understand why<p>‘Why did it take them so long to tell anyone?” This is a question we often hear at SurvivorsUK, especially when a high-profile trial, such as that of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/15/barry-bennell-abuse-manchester-city-crewe" title="">Barry Bennell</a>, is in the news.</p><p>Based on an analysis of our client data from a few years ago, we estimate that the average length of time it takes the men who we support to come forward is 26 years. And this is the average for the men who <em>do</em> come forward. We cannot know how many men never come forward, never report to the police and never ask for help. It has been estimated that this could be as high as 96% and that as many as one in six men has experienced sexual violence. Perhaps the kinder and more revealing question to ask is: “How is it that these men did report, given that so few do?”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/if-abused-cant-speak-we-need-other-routes-to-their-pain-barry-bennell">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'The fight ain’t over': the Sydney Mardi Gras after the marriage vote</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/18/the-fight-aint-over-the-sydney-mardi-gras-after-the-marriage-vote</link>
      <description><p>The two-week festival is close to unrecognisable from its first incarnation in 1978</p><p>Rainbow flags are flying again in Sydney. They had barely been put back in the cupboard after celebrations over the passing of Australia’s marriage equality law before the LGBT community’s attention turned to the 40th anniversary of the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras. </p><p>The theme this year is “40 years of evolution” – a nod to the fact the event has been both protest and festival, according to Mardi Gras creative director Greg Clarke, but also to the changing political landscape in which the festival now exists: exemplified by the 61.6% of Australians who voted in favour of marriage equality last year in a postal survey, and the sheer visibility of a festival that now attracts hundreds of thousands of people to inner-city Sydney. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/18/the-fight-aint-over-the-sydney-mardi-gras-after-the-marriage-vote">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/sydney-mardi-gras-">Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/sydney">Sydney</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/lgbt-rights">LGBT rights</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australia-news">Australia news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/new-south-wales">New South Wales</category>
      <pubDate>Sat, 17 Feb 2018 19:00:23 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/18/the-fight-aint-over-the-sydney-mardi-gras-after-the-marriage-vote</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/6bc555df7ec175aa5cdb652e8dae594c7c2175d3/0_0_2362_1418/master/2362.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=f628c9343c8f4c9acc5ed40a5763b0a5">

      <title>No record of some threatened species in area government says it's protecting them</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/17/no-record-of-some-threatened-species-in-area-government-says-its-protecting-them</link>
      <description><p>Experts say growling grass frog and southern brown bandicoot not likely to be found at Endeavour Fern Gully<br></p><p>Experts have cast doubt on government claims the Coalition is funding a conservation project in Victoria’s Endeavour Fern Gully to benefit threatened species – because the listed species are unlikely to occur in the area. </p><p>Endeavour Fern Gully is a 27-hectare (65 acre) rainforest property on the Mornington Peninsula<em>. </em>The environment and energy minister, Josh Frydenberg, says the government had funded a broad Green Army project<em> </em>that “improves habitat through weed control and promotes greater conservation awareness of native vegetation in remnant bushland at Endeavour Fern Gully”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/17/no-record-of-some-threatened-species-in-area-government-says-its-protecting-them">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/16/liberal-mp-caught-on-open-mic-using-four-letter-word-on-murray-darling-plan</link>
      <description><p>Tony Pasin tells Murray-Darling Basin Authority’s Phillip Glyde the plan took 100 years to make but ‘one night to fuck it up’</p><p>A government MP has been caught joking with the head of the Murray-Darling Basin Authority about who’s had a worse week, before quipping that the basin plan took 100 years to make but “one night to fuck it up”.</p><p>Microphones picked up the conversation between Liberal MP Tony Pasin and the chief executive of the MDBA, Phillip Glyde, just before Glyde was due to give evidence to a Senate inquiry into regional development and decentralisation in Canberra.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/16/liberal-mp-caught-on-open-mic-using-four-letter-word-on-murray-darling-plan">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/admiral-warns-us-must-prepare-for-possibility-of-war-with-china</link>
      <description><p>Harry Harris, the next US ambassador to Australia, says Beijing intends to control South China Sea</p><p>The <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2018/feb/10/admiral-harry-harris-named-us-ambassador-to-australia">navy admiral nominated to be the next US ambassador to Australia</a> has told Congress America must prepare for the possibility of war with China, and said it would rely on Australia to help uphold the international rules-based system in the Asia-Pacific.</p><p>In an excoriating assessment of China’s increasingly muscular posture in the region, Harry Harris said Beijing’s “intent is crystal clear” to dominate the South China Sea and that its military might could soon rival American power “across almost every domain”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/16/admiral-warns-us-must-prepare-for-possibility-of-war-with-china">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Israel’s military says it targeted Hamas positions after IED on border injured four troops</p><p>Israel has used jets and tanks to strike the Gaza Strip in response to the explosion of an improvised explosive device that wounded four of its soldiers, marking one of the most severe escalations of violence since the 2014 war. </p><p>Gaza’s Hamas-run government said two Palestinian 17-year-olds were killed by Israeli tank fire during Saturday night’s attacks, sending photos to journalists of what appeared to be two bodies on stretchers.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/four-israeli-soldiers-injured-two-seriously-in-border-blast">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Supporters of deported former Georgian leader demand impeachment of Ukrainian president</p><p>Thousands of supporters of the deported former Georgian leader Mikheil Saakashvili have marched through the streets of Kiev, demanding the impeachment of the Ukrainian president.</p><p>Journalists said an estimated 10,000 people took part in the rally on Sunday, though the ministry of internal affairs put the number at about 3,000. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/saakashvili-supporters-march-in-kiev-calling-for-president-to-quit">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/18/farming-businesses-could-be-wiped-out-after-brexit-transition</link>
      <description><p>Select committee says government needs contingency plans to protect consumers and businesses from impact from tariffs</p><p>Food prices could rise sharply and farming businesses could be wiped out at the end of a Brexit transition period, a House of Commons committee has warned.</p><p>The cross-party environment, food and rural affairs select committee said the timetable for concluding a new free trade deal with the EU by the end of 2020 was “extremely ambitious”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/18/farming-businesses-could-be-wiped-out-after-brexit-transition">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ukip's Gerard Batten reiterates his belief that Islam is a 'death cult'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-gerard-batten-islam-muslims-quran</link>
      <description><p>Interim leader says Muslims should sign a document renouncing parts of the Qur’an</p><p>Ukip’s interim leader, Gerard Batten, has reiterated his belief that Islam is a “death cult” and called for Muslims to be asked to sign a document renouncing parts of the Qur’an, in remarks that risk pushing the beleaguered party even further from the mainstream.</p><p>Batten, an MEP for London, took over as party head on Saturday after <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-members-oust-henry-bolton-as-leader-after-five-months">Henry Bolton was removed</a> at an emergency general meeting of party members, called when Bolton refused to step down following controversy about his personal affairs.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/ukip-gerard-batten-islam-muslims-quran">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/afghan-provincial-governor-defies-ghanis-order-to-step-down</link>
      <description><p>Leader of Samangan province is second governor to defy president, exposing Ghani’s weakness</p><p>A second Afghan provincial governor has defied an attempt by President Ashraf Ghani to remove him, deepening a political crisis that has underlined the weakness of the western-backed government in Kabul.</p><p> Abdulkarim Khaddam, governor of the northern province of Samangan, followed the leader of neighbouring Balkh province, Atta Mohammad Noor, in rejecting an order to step down, issued last week as part of a shakeup of regional governors.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/afghan-provincial-governor-defies-ghanis-order-to-step-down">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/donald-trump-hr-mcmaster-russia-election-meddling-investigation</link>
      <description><p>HR McMaster calls evidence incontrovertible in wake of latest US indictments against more than a dozen Russians </p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">Mueller charges 13 Russians with interfering in US election to help Trump</a></li></ul><p>Donald Trump’s national security adviser, HR McMaster, said on Saturday that Russian meddling in the 2016 election is “incontrovertible” and “beyond dispute” in the wake of new US indictments.</p><p>McMaster spoke after Robert Mueller, the special counsel in the Russia investigation, revealed new details about Moscow’s sophisticated cyber-meddling campaign on Friday.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/donald-trump-hr-mcmaster-russia-election-meddling-investigation">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Unthinkable for EU to agree to PM’s key demand on citizens’ rights, says Verhofstadt</p><p>Theresa May’s demand that EU nationals coming to the UK during a Brexit transition deal should enjoy fewer rights than those already in the country would amount to “penalising citizens”, Guy Verhofstadt has said.</p><p>Verhofstadt, the European parliament’s Brexit coordinator, said May was “not very serious” when she proposed the idea.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/18/theresa-may-brexit-transition-demand-demonise-eu-citizens-verhofstadt">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The view from the front row: a history of the fashion show – photo essay</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/15/the-view-from-the-front-row-a-history-of-the-fashion-show-photo-essay</link>
      <description><p>Once, photographers were banned from fashion shows, with designers suspecting they were spies. Today, fashion shows are a multimillion-dollar global business. As London fashion week begins, we cart the evolution of the fashion show, from secret salons to the snap-happy Instagram era</p><p>Most fashion shows last less than 10 minutes, but have the power to transport an audience to another world. There’s an intensity to a great show, a distillation of a designer’s extraordinary vision. </p><p>Once upon a time, though, things were a lot humbler. The intimate salon shows of Chanel in the 1950s bear no resemblance to Karl Lagerfeld’s fully-stocked supermarket in the vast Grand Palais in 2014. The main change is scale – along with location, set production, and budget. From John Galliano’s historical dramas at Christian Dior, to Hussein Chalayan’s theatrical impossibilities and the late Alexander McQueen’s gothic, heart-stopping wonders, we chart how the fashion show developed from low-key to king.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2018/feb/15/the-view-from-the-front-row-a-history-of-the-fashion-show-photo-essay">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Urban landscapes reimagined – in pictures</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2018/feb/17/urban-landscapes-reimagined-in-pictures</link>
      <description><p>For Serbian photographer <a href="http://structurephotography.org/">Nikola Olic</a>, the built environment is a canvas for his inventive compositions. Using only a single camera and minimal Photoshopping, Olic creates abstract images that present the metropolis in a new light: “Instead of just taking a photograph, I move around a building and slightly change and adjust the composition,” he says. “The object is manipulated by walking, zooming, checking sun angles, climbing garages…” Now based in Texas, Olic has focused largely on US cities, including New York, Chicago and Dallas, but he has also shot in Tokyo and Barcelona. Citing Michael Wolf, Oscar Niemeyer and Andreas Gursky as influences, he calls his work “structure photography”, explaining that it “offers a playful reimagining of what urban structures might represent”. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2018/feb/17/urban-landscapes-reimagined-in-pictures">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Shape of Water review – a seductively melancholy creature feature</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/18/the-shape-of-water-review-guillermo-del-toro-sally-hawkins</link>
      <description><p>Guillermo del Toro’s magical movie, a cold war thriller, is underpinned by a superb cast and knowing nods to Hollywood classics</p><p>In my opinion, the 21st century has produced no finer movie than <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/nov/05/features.review1"><em>Pan’s Labyrinth</em></a>, Guillermo del Toro’s 2006 masterpiece, which acts as a sister picture to his 2001 Spanish civil war ghost story, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/News_Story/Critic_Review/Observer_review/0,,610241,00.html"><em>The Devil’s Backbone</em></a>. Like Del Toro’s first feature, <em>Cronos</em> (1993), these Spanish-language gems possessed a unique cinematic voice, the distant echo of which could still be heard even amid the thunderous roar of 2013’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/jul/14/pacific-rim-review-philip-french"><em>Pacific Rim</em></a>. Now, with his awards-garlanded latest (co-scripted by <em>Game of Thrones</em> graduate Vanessa Taylor), Del Toro has conjured a boundary-crossing hybrid that is as adventurously personal as it is universal, a swooning romantic melodrama that reshapes the mythical themes of Beauty and the Beast with deliciously bestial bite.</p><p>An opening voiceover establishes the fable-like tone, setting the story “a long time ago” in “a small city near the coast, but far from everything else”. This is the US in the early-60s, with the cold war and the space race providing the backdrop for “a tale of love and loss and the monster who tried to destroy it all”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2018/feb/18/the-shape-of-water-review-guillermo-del-toro-sally-hawkins">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Will Young: ‘Our podcast is a queer Woman's Hour’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/will-young-our-podcast-is-a-queer-womans-hour-homo-sapiens</link>
      <description><p>Homo Sapiens is a frank and funny podcast hosted by Will Young and film director Chris Sweeney. Mark Smith joins them on tour in the north of England</p><p>Will Young hasn’t been to a sexual health clinic before so our hosts at Manchester’s <a href="http://lgbt.foundation/">LGBT Foundation</a>, a community charity near the city’s gay village, are keen to impress upon him that sandwiches and cakes do not come as standard for its service users. “They’re posh ones from the deli – not the Greggs stuff we usually lay on for visitors,” remarks Peter Brampton, a sparky sexual health project leader.</p><p>Young and his film director friend Chris Sweeney are here as part of their tour of the north of England for the second season of their rose-tinted yet highly successful podcast <a href="http://homosapienspodcast.com/"><em>Homo Sapiens</em></a>. The first series heard the pair chatting to LGBTQ+ luminaries, such as the trans actor <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/aug/22/rebecca-root-interview-not-fighting-myself-any-more">Rebecca Root</a>, actor <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/bisi-alimi">Bisi Alimi</a> (who caused fury in his native Nigeria by <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2016/feb/09/bisi-alimi-on-lgbt-rights-in-nigeria-it-may-take-60-years-but-we-have-to-start-now">coming out</a> on television) and human rights activist <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/petertatchell">Peter Tatchell</a>. A visit to his tiny London flat was poignant, with Young somehow managing to convey the depths of Tatchell’s personal sacrifice with fretful asides about the dusty clutter.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/feb/18/will-young-our-podcast-is-a-queer-womans-hour-homo-sapiens">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The unequal battle: privilege, genes, gender and power | @Anna_Kessel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/the-unequal-battle-privilege-genes-gender-and-power</link>
      <description><p>The tense debate around Caster Semenya and Dutee Chand demonstrate the intersection between race, gender and medical imperialism</p><p>When I was eight years old I visited South Africa, my dad’s homeland, for the first time. I’ll never forget flying into Jo’burg, looking down over the houses in the city and seeing hundreds of turquoise squiggles and dots. “Wow,” I said, excitedly, “everyone has a swimming pool here!”<br></p><p>My dad gave me a stern look. “Not everyone,” he said. It was 1987 and apartheid was in its final throes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/the-unequal-battle-privilege-genes-gender-and-power">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>US feminist Susan Brownmiller on why her groundbreaking book on rape is still relevant</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/susan-brownmiller-against-our-will-interview-metoo</link>
      <description><p>Against Our Will brought rape out of the shadows in 1975. As the world reels from the #MeToo allegations, Brownmiller talks about pornography, power and 70s radical feminism</p><p>In the more than 40 years since its publication, Susan Brownmiller’s controversial, groundbreaking book about rape, <em>Against Our Will</em>, has never been out of print. It has, though, often been out of people’s minds – until now, that is. Thanks to the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/harvey-weinstein" title="">allegations against Harvey Weinstein</a> and all that has followed in their wake, Brownmiller’s work is suddenly crisp again, its prescience and enduring relevance noted anew by anyone old enough, or well read enough, to be familiar with it. In <a href="https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2017/11/20/the-weinstein-moment-and-the-trump-presidency" title="">a piece for the <em>New Yorker</em> last November</a>, the magazine’s editor, David Remnick, used the adjective “startling” to describe it. Its author, he reminded his readers, got there first when it came to illustrating that sexual coercion is less a matter of lust than of power; and she made it her business to bust the myth that women “cry rape with ease and glee”. If that fallacy still prevails, this only shows how right she was to confront it in the first place.</p><p>After the article appeared, Brownmiller, who is now 82, expected a gentle upswing in her emails, perhaps the odd visit from a journalist. But, no. There followed a period of radio silence. “Turns out my details online were wrong, or something,” she says, with a cackle, lighting yet another cigarette. In her luxuriantly carpeted penthouse flat high at the top of a tower in Greenwich Village, New York, she was left alone to watch as #MeToo rolled like a huge boulder through the national conversation. What does she make of it so far? “Oh, I think it is a wonderful rise on the part of women,” she says, unhesitatingly. “People like me thought it [harassment] was all settled, and it was astonishing to find out that it wasn’t. The need to talk out, I find promising. It’s cathartic. It’s also very sad, of course. Sexual harassment was quantified by the law long ago. It’s been hard coming to terms with the fact that a lot of what we accomplished seems somehow just to have been erased.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/susan-brownmiller-against-our-will-interview-metoo">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Amid the chaos of Syria, will Israel and Iran launch an all-out war?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/amid-chaos-syria-will-israel-iran-launch-all-out-war</link>
      <description>Neither country will benefit from a new Middle East conflict, but unless they cease military clashes, such as those inside Syria last weekend, hopes of peace remain fragile<p>Tensions between Israel and Iran have hit a new high following last weekend’s unprecedented <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/10/israeli-fighter-jet-shot-down-by-syrian-fire-says-military" title="">military clashes inside Syria</a>. The fighting has intensified fears that the Middle East is heading for all-out war. But such alarming predictions assume both protagonists standing toe-to-toe, actuallywant to fight. Is this reallytrue?</p><p>Iran is portrayed as a wanton aggressor, especially by the Trump administration and the Saudis. It has steadily expanded its military presence in Syria since supporting Bashar al-Assad after 2011, deploying Afghan and Pakistani Shia militias, Lebanese Hezbollah fighters and its own Revolutionary Guards.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/18/amid-chaos-syria-will-israel-iran-launch-all-out-war">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Putin’s chef, a troll farm and Russia's plot to hijack US democracy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/putins-chef-a-troll-farm-and-russias-plot-to-hijack-us-democracy</link>
      <description><p>Robert Mueller has revealed audacious meddling in the 2016 election. Can he link it to Trump?</p><p>The plot against America began in 2014. Thousands of miles away, in a drab office building in St Petersburg, Russia, a fake newsroom was under construction with its own graphics, data analysis, search engine optimisation, IT and finance departments. Its mission: ”information warfare against the United States of America”.</p><p>What followed, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/16/robert-mueller-russians-charged-election">according to an indictment</a> brought by the US special counsel, Robert Mueller, on Friday, was a stunningly successful attack on the most powerful democracy in the world. It involved stolen identities, fake social media accounts, rallies organised from afar, US citizens duped into doing Moscow’s bidding, and two Russians going undercover in a ruse reminiscent of <em>The Americans</em>, a TV drama about KGB spies in suburban Washington during the cold war.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/17/putins-chef-a-troll-farm-and-russias-plot-to-hijack-us-democracy">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Vegas Tenold, author of Everything You Love Will Burn: Inside the Rebirth of White Nationalism in America, tells of his reporting on the far right</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/americas-far-right-white-supremacists-nationalism">America’s dark underbelly: I watched the rise of white nationalism</a></li></ul><p>The Norwegian journalist Vegas Tenold started reporting on neo-Nazi and KKK rallies in 2011, six years before <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/13/charlottesville-white-supremacists-far-right-donald-trump-confederate-statue">the violent clashes</a> in Charlottesville, Virginia, that made the resurgence of white supremacist groups into an international news story. </p><p>Tenold’s new book, Everything You Love Will Burn: Inside the Rebirth of White Nationalism in America, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/17/americas-far-right-white-supremacists-nationalism">excerpted here</a>, chronicles the experience of those six years.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/feb/17/vegas-tenold-everything-you-love-will-burn-q-and-a-nazis">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>A letter to… the ‘rude’ woman who saved my daughter’s life</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/a-letter-to-the-rude-woman-who-saved-my-daughters-life</link>
      <description><p>‘Thank you for beeping your horn when you did, for seeing what I hadn’t seen’: the letter you always wanted to write</p><p>It was about seven years ago. I had just picked up my three-year-old daughter from nursery. I was weighed down with shopping, and with my daughter’s things. She scooted alongside me. We arrived at a pedestrian crossing and she pressed the button. In the distance, I heard sirens, told my daughter to wait and watched the police car approach.</p><p>Little did I know, as the green man flashed, that my daughter had begun to scoot into the road. I watched the police car speed towards us – that’s when you beeped your horn and waved frantically to me. My daughter was about a metre from the path of the police car, hidden from their view by your car.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/feb/17/a-letter-to-the-rude-woman-who-saved-my-daughters-life">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘I’m a pot evangelist’: meet America's dope queens</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/17/cannabis-pot-evangelist-america-dope-queens</link>
      <description><p>As more US states legalise marijuana, more women are stepping up to meet the need for weed. Meet the entrepreneurs cutting through the stigma</p><p>Like most other American industries, marijuana has traditionally been dominated by men. Overwhelmingly they grew it, they dealt it and they smoked it. Hopes that the legal marijuana industry would be more egalitarian than others have largely deflated. According to a 2017 survey, women hold <a href="https://mjbizdaily.com/chart-portion-women-executives-cannabis-dips-27-still-strong/">27% of executive positions in cannabis</a>, only slightly more than in the country at large. Nevertheless, the plant’s status as a quasi-legal drug has created an opportunity for women to forge groundbreaking careers.</p><p>Cannabis businesses are obsessed with tearing down the stigma that continues to dog the plant. Many of the most ambitious companies want to make inroads with affluent adults and parents who don’t use, or no longer use, cannabis; if the prevailing stereotype is that weed is a drug used by low-achieving men, the thinking is that women will be better at getting their husbands and boyfriends to use pot.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/17/cannabis-pot-evangelist-america-dope-queens">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/b70c8055b93582341bdccea3ac3e862be23bb3bc/0_575_5470_3282/master/5470.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=5d40d003d8a7a7bea322a61879a80b55">
